{"id_":"b0783b57-5066-4e32-9fed-85041db239f3","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"./datasources/medaica/Medaica website.html","metadata":{},"hash":"IpYTHJP0214uZp+lLM+gBbVALzrA7VQSGzS0kfHk0+I="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"46722c22-86bd-4b8c-b792-09d517d9736a","metadata":{},"hash":"ihccHlSHhfmIQPuWDBzZPXWFtKPVNZrMhYbzuiqU9Co="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"0c5ad4be-41a7-4e32-ac8e-0e7d299d362f","metadata":{},"hash":"9zgnGLX6HFkoTWrEhWniHu85trI38aPdRz8xddiTaso="}},"hash":"J97mA+RI3Bk5zzV+TZp7G+uDB1XGtSMsW7/QVmvQqpU=","text":"​ Growth of "Digital First" 82% Consumer Digital Health ​

82% of consumers view digital options as the best way to monitor health

​ ​

​

McKinsey 2021 94% Interoperability ​

94% of healthcare professionals believe interoperability is critical. ​ ​

​

Deloitte Insights 2020 860M ​

​

CDC Fact Sheet 2019 Physician Office Visits in USA in 2019 ​

503M Primary Care consultations in USA in 2019. ​ 85% ​

209,000 Primary Care Physicians in USA

​ Adults visited a Dr. last year ​

​

CDC Fact Sheet 2019 1.4M Patients in Licensed Nursing Homes in USA in 2019

​

​ ​

​

CDC Fact Sheet 2019 65M 20% people in the USA have been diagnosed with heart disease 27M, Asthma 25M, COPD 23M. ​

​

CDC Fact Sheet 2019 products Medaica Telehealth+ Telehealth diagnostic platform with FREE FDA-cleared stethoscope for remote auscultation. ​

- Improve the efficiency of supporting remote patients with more exam data and better outcomes. ​

Medaica Telehealth+ is an affordable and effective way for providers to extend their remote health capabilities. ​

More than basic telehealth video conferencing, Medaica Telehealth+ is a connected care platform that combines audio/video features with diagnostic tools and an FDA-cleared, Over The Counter (OTC) stethoscope, specifically designed for plug-and-play remote auscultation, so healthcare professionals can listen to a remote patient as easily and clearly as if they were in the clinic. MEDAICA TELEHEALTH+ FEATURES
Cloud-based telehealth platform

Works with Chrome or any browser supporting Web RTC. Supported platforms: iOS 15 and up, iPadOS 15 and up, Android 12 and up, Windows 10 and up, MacOS 10 and up. Live, Store and Forward, Scheduled and In-Person. Nurse assisted. 3rd Party AI diagnostic support. Secure. encrypted end-to-end, HIPAA compliant. M1 Telehealth Stethoscope. FDA cleared 510(k), Class II, OTC, intended to be used by professional users in a clinical environment or by lay users 18+ (and approved for over 65 yrs old) in a nonclinical environment.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

0c5ad4be-41a7-4e32-ac8e-0e7d299d362f.__data__:
{"id_":"0c5ad4be-41a7-4e32-ac8e-0e7d299d362f","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"./datasources/medaica/Medaica website.html","metadata":{},"hash":"IpYTHJP0214uZp+lLM+gBbVALzrA7VQSGzS0kfHk0+I="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"b0783b57-5066-4e32-9fed-85041db239f3","metadata":{},"hash":"J97mA+RI3Bk5zzV+TZp7G+uDB1XGtSMsW7/QVmvQqpU="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"5fe104c1-011b-482b-ba8a-dc7fa161d501","metadata":{},"hash":"psnCir3f6oxuktsSybz343iqalUCP0BpMAaT2iiTmoI="}},"hash":"9zgnGLX6HFkoTWrEhWniHu85trI38aPdRz8xddiTaso=","text":"Specifically designed for remote auscultation, patented two microphone design for intuitive multi-modal patient/ provider communications and auscultation recording. Frequency response 20 - 3,500 Hz. USB-C with included USB-2 and Lightning adapters. Live-stream and near real-time lossless upload. PCG visualization. FREE for strategic partners supporting rural, or underserved patients and chronic heart and/or lung conditions. Save and share recordings allowing for benchmarking, longitudinal and cohort comparisons. Noise reduction: ambient, room and frictional. Dimensions 134.5 x 17.5 x 33.4 mm. IP24. Healthcare Provider interface includes stethoscope volume, bell, diaphragm and extended filters, auscultation position customization, auscultation notes, patient messaging, waiting room, patient present alert, and export to EMR. Remotely detect patient’s stethoscope status and record start/stop. Use Cases

Remote exams (e.g. rural, schools, corporate), Chronic patient follow up, reduce readmissions, clinical education, in field EMS triage and clinical support. HOW TO BUY

Medaica Telehealth+ is available via RPM or telehealth partners or sold to HCPs as either an annual license on a per visit/per stethoscope or per host model. The FDA cleared Medaica M1 Stethoscope is also available FREE for strategic partners supporting rural, or underserved patients and chronic heart and/or lung conditions. Contact us. Contact Us End-to-End Virtual Care Use Cases Our Cause MEDAICA is working on a cause-driven campaign under the banner of EveryBeatEveryBreath.org, to provide telehealth solutions with free stethoscopes to remote, underserved communities and disadvantaged groups. In the USA, nearly 53 million people (16% of population) live more than 30 miles from a hospital or urgent care. Globally, an estimated one billion people have no access to essential health-care services. The campaign aims to raise awareness of this issue and underpins MEDAICA’s Mission "to extend the reach and capability of remote care” and Vision that “Everyone in the world has affordable access to healthcare. ”

Contact us to learn more. ​

EveryBeatEveryBreath.org Cause About us

We are passionate about making remote care available to everyone, simply and affordably.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

5fe104c1-011b-482b-ba8a-dc7fa161d501.__data__:
{"id_":"5fe104c1-011b-482b-ba8a-dc7fa161d501","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"./datasources/medaica/Medaica website.html","metadata":{},"hash":"IpYTHJP0214uZp+lLM+gBbVALzrA7VQSGzS0kfHk0+I="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"0c5ad4be-41a7-4e32-ac8e-0e7d299d362f","metadata":{},"hash":"9zgnGLX6HFkoTWrEhWniHu85trI38aPdRz8xddiTaso="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"7a3fcf48-970c-4c8f-9151-14533886a992","metadata":{},"hash":"55Su/U2I1rF3G7QoHof9LCZMixazp9oQ2/al3mAlvfA="}},"hash":"psnCir3f6oxuktsSybz343iqalUCP0BpMAaT2iiTmoI=","text":"Medaica was founded by serial entrepreneurs with multiple successful exits, a combined 50+ years in health technology and medical businesses and over 100 years in software platforms. Our team has the unique experience of designing, developing and shipping innovative, robust, secure and scalable software and consumer electronics, used by hundreds of millions of people worldwide. We have helped catalyze change in other industries and we are working to do the same in digital health. Starting by making it more open and interoperable, enabling AI and other products and services to leverage data. Ultimately, we believe open platforms will accelerate innovation and lead to more efficient and more affordable healthcare and better outcomes. For everyone. ​

Partnerships are critical to achieving what we're building. Please contact us to learn more. about-us Leadership STEPHEN RANDALL

CEO Stephen is serial entrepreneur with global experience building technology platform businesses. Prior to Medaica, he was COO of M3dicine, a MedTech device company and CEO of LocaModa Inc., a Digital Out of Home platform company (acquired by Monster Media). Stephen was also a Founder and COO of Symbian, the mobile OS platform company jointly owned by Nokia, Sony Ericsson, Motorola, Matsushita, Motorola and Psion (acquired by Nokia), Joint CEO of Psion Software PLC., a mobile computing company and Founder/CEO of Eden Group (acquired by Geoworks). He is a recipient of the British Design Award for the Stepp Digital Guitar. Architecture - Cardiff University. PABLO RIVAS

President / CFO Before MEDAICA, Pablo was CFO at M3dicine a MedTech company and CEO of AmeriMed, the largest chain of American hospitals in Mexico where he led the company turnaround. With 15 years of experience in M&A at European and American banks, he led multiple cross-border deals in Healthcare, Biotech, Health Insurance and Pharma. Besides Medaica, he co-founded 2 companies in the technology space, both currently in growth stage and advised many others. Angel investor. Pablo holds a Wharton MBA, MA in International Studies from Univ. of Penn/Lauder Institute and a post-grad degree in Mgmt. from Harvard University.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

7a3fcf48-970c-4c8f-9151-14533886a992.__data__:
{"id_":"7a3fcf48-970c-4c8f-9151-14533886a992","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"./datasources/medaica/Medaica website.html","metadata":{},"hash":"IpYTHJP0214uZp+lLM+gBbVALzrA7VQSGzS0kfHk0+I="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"5fe104c1-011b-482b-ba8a-dc7fa161d501","metadata":{},"hash":"psnCir3f6oxuktsSybz343iqalUCP0BpMAaT2iiTmoI="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"17cbdbae-0802-4223-a227-a6d64bf9c600","metadata":{},"hash":"j6gsSxuSqAXB3mQNzFLrBErd0nlxHw2//Aqt4/2J0mU="}},"hash":"55Su/U2I1rF3G7QoHof9LCZMixazp9oQ2/al3mAlvfA=","text":"from Harvard University. CLIVE MILLINGTON

COO Consumer and technology product expert who has deployed >100million connected devices in over 40 countries globally (Satnav, Health-tech and Sports wearables). Former CEO of AYR and over 12 years as COO of TomTom N.V., digital map and content provider. Over 35 years’ experience in early-stage companies through to IPO and onto consumer brands with global recognition. Builder of high-performance companies, products and teams. Deep expertise in supply chain and operations management. MBA - Univ. Hertfordshire. MARK GRETTON

CTO Mark has over thirty years of technology management including senior  management/CTO roles at several start ups including  Psion PLC where he developed one of the first ARM based application specific processor chips. Former CTO of TomTom N.V. where he led the transition from a small software company into a large international consumer electronics brand. He built the engineering team that developed the company’s ground-breaking range of navigation and Health-tech devices with over a 100m units sold. BSc Engineering - University of Reading. DR. JENNIFER PEÑA

Chief Medical Officer Dr. Peña served as White House physician under both the Obama and Trump administrations, and Physician to the Vice President of the United States. A former US Army combat veteran, Dr. Peña is a digital and telehealth expert, clinical leader and board-certified internal medicine physician. Dr. Peña directs the Vidalús free clinic of the Boys and Girls Club of Puerto Rico and is a fellow of the American College of Physicians (ACP) and member of the American Telemedicine Association's Advisory Group to Eliminate Healthcare Disparities and Inequalities. BS-Yale University. MD-University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine. Residency-Walter Reed Army Medical Center. NICK GIESCHEN

Head of Software Before MEDAICA, Nick was founder and Head of Software at Double Down Interactive (acquired by IGT) an entertainment software company. Nick led platform development from concept, and launch, to scale to 4.7 million monthly active users and exit ($500M). Prior to Double Down Interactive, Nick had 20+ years developing software platforms for startups and Fortune 100 companies such as IBM, AT&T, and Intel. Angel investor.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

BA, Philosophy and Literature – Univ of Toronto DAN GIESCHEN

Head of Product 20+ years experience developing high-end technology applications and solutions. Before MEDAICA Dan was CPO of iPro and helped develop the product. Prior to iPro, Dan was founder and Head of Product at Double Down Interactive (acquired by IGT) an entertainment software company that he helped to grow to support over 1 million daily players, 100+ employees, and one of the top grossing iPad and Facebook applications. Dan is also Head of Technology for Drop in the Bucket, a non-profit building wells and sanitations systems at schools in Africa. Board member at IndieFlix Group Inc. Angel Investor. Berklee College of Music Clinical Advisory Board Medaica’s Clinical Advisory Board help the company continuously improve our products

by identifying areas where we add the most value to providers and patients. The board comprises world-renowned clinicians spanning the The White House Medical Unit,

Emory, USCSF and the International Institute of Cardiology. Dr. Byron Williams Jr. is Emeritus Chief of Medicine    at Emory University Hospital. He received his medical degree from University of Florida College of Medicine. Dr. Vicente Bertomeu is the Dean of Cardiology at UMH in Elche (Spain) and the Head of the Cardiology Research Center    at San Juan University  Hospital, Alicante, Spain. Dr. Jennifer Peña served as White House physician under both the Obama and Trump administrations, and Physician to the Vice President of the United States. A digital and telehealth expert, clinical leader and board-certified internal medicine physician. Julie Gregg is a Certified Registered Nurse Anesthetist at the Veterans Administration in the USA and is a Principal Investigator for research investigating systolic and diastolic duration. Laurie McGraw is a recognized healthcare leader, previously American Medical Association (AMA) SVP; President AMA Innovations; President at Allscripts. Dr. Danny Weiss is a cardiac electrophysiologist and an author of “An in vitro acoustic analysis and comparison of popular stethoscopes” a leading peer reviewed white paper for digital stethoscope performance testing. Dr. Adithya Cattamanchi is Professor of Medicine and Epidemiology at UCSF and UC Irvine.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

7b2d30ab-e1c8-4f05-b0a2-fb6466b53aa8.__data__:
{"id_":"7b2d30ab-e1c8-4f05-b0a2-fb6466b53aa8","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"IfadRCX9L3SzXmgJe3wuzMK6oodCJ96/CpDhJ9p1Qu4=","metadata":{},"hash":"SS5Vz5vX4BsQ1bxTbdfFTRjojCtj1m3//7MGzsmt6Mk="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"a19edca8-3197-4619-8776-44c76fb212d6","metadata":{},"hash":"hQQzrcQG5F06FrriLO93Uok23qelaM39cOSYtjhQWBo="}},"hash":"pp+3tK2mFDxK6qhxgSdo/6vfEVcJdQW03ATDTLWrrw8=","text":"Early diagnosis and management of chronic heart and lung conditions. The U.S. has the lowest life expectancy compared to other developed nations and the highest 
rate for avoidable deaths. Source: Commonwealth Fund 
1 person dies every 33 secs of cardiovascular disease. 7 in 10 deaths are from chronic disease. >50% of the population live with chronic disease. Heart Failure affects over 26 million people 
- 6.5 Million adults in U.S costing $60 billion annually. - Ranked 2
nd
 in top 20 expensive conditions billed to Medicare. - In top 5 most expensive conditions treated in the U.S. - 75 million in U.S. living with risk of developing HF. - 12 - 15 million office visits and 6.5 million hospital days /year. - Leading cause of hospitalization for people over 65. - The HF price tag in EU is even higher. More than entire EU budget at $282 billion in 2021. Source: NIH and European Society of Cardiology 
Early diagnosis saves lives 
and money. $3.3 Trillion (80%) U.S health care spent on chronic disease. $216 Billion on cardiovascular disease. (Source: cdc) 
We can do better... Low-cost interoperable digital sensors + smart software can detect: 
Murmurs 
- Abnormal Murmurs can indicate: Heart failure, Infection of valves or inner lining (infective 
endocarditis), Blood clots and stroke, Fainting, Heart attack, Sudden cardiac arrest, Fever, 
Anemia, or Valvular Heart Disease (VHD). A narrow valve -  possibly due to aortic stenosis. - Hear murmurs, tell which valve is in trouble, evaluate the severity. Valve leakage. - Hear the tell-tale sounds of a leaky valve, pinpoint which valve is leaking  and the amount of 
blood leaking. Arrhythmias. - Normal or abnormal heart rhythm called an arrhythmia, like atrial fibrillation. No other company offers low-cost, interoperable digital sensors + smart software... No other platform enables affordable access to early diagnosis 
They are: 
• >10x cost. • Not designed for consumers. • Not designed for virtual/remote use case. • Not interoperable. • Proprietary/Closed.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

252555b5-a505-4355-bfdc-24849fded61d.__data__:
{"id_":"252555b5-a505-4355-bfdc-24849fded61d","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"rMtU7Ur1ylochD0gXXbKi81unjHa2BWxcTUbAAi4roQ=","metadata":{},"hash":"U5BdRVoCgckESTYQVGkTpn/Lg8OY2B5+HNkFuH4/fmo="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"c0b74a90-2461-433e-b22a-6bf982e30c6d","metadata":{},"hash":"V7roThaRUf8uaoOXmoX2efywAUaxHaF2JInpHSN/IjE="}},"hash":"cCudhWL7jp7voNCqZCfRgwDOonBVbkUh5SJs56VFyFg=","text":"Former founder, COO Symbian, first global mobile OS platform, reaching 100 million users 
(acquired by Nokia). Former CEO of LocaModa, Digital Out of Home (acquired by Monster 
Media). Pablo Rivas 
President & CFO 
Former CEO AmeriMed, the largest chain of US hospitals in Mexico. 15 years M&A at US and 
EU banks leading Healthcare, Biotech, Health and Pharma. Dr. Peña 
CMO 
Former White House physician  in Obama & Trump administrations. Former US Army combat 
veteran of 15 years. American Telehealth Association Advisory Group  
Mark Gretton 
CTO 
Former CTO TomTom, navtech pioneers, reaching 800 million users  via devices and software. Former CTO Psion PLC designing first ARM silicon. Dan Gieschen 
CPO 
Former founder DoubleDown, a  top 20 grossing mobile game with 5 million monthly active 
users. Acquired by IDG  for $500M. Clive Millington 
COO  
Former COO of TomTom. Over 35 years’ experience in early-stage companies through to IPO with deep expertise in 
supply chain and ops management. Bernardo Plaza  
Head of Reg & QA 
Former founder of eKuore, first wireless digital stethoscope company. 10+ years experience 
managing Regulatory and Quality functions in healthcare industry. Intellectual Property 
Virtual Healthcare Exam Systems and Methods - PENDING 
Systems and methods are provided to enable a healthcare professional to conduct a remote 
exam from any web-enabled audio and/or video platform, not only simplifying telemedicine 
consultations that would otherwise require special devices and/or integration of disparate 
systems but also increasing the value of the telemedicine consultation. Virtual Healthcare Audio Systems and Methods - PENDING 
A second “room” microphone is added to a telemedicine audio exam device such as but not 
limited to a stethoscope. One embodiment of such as system includes the ability for the patient 
to maintain communications with a healthcare professional even if their device is placed on 
their body. The healthcare professional and/or the system can switch the room microphone off 
when they need better signal to noise for the examination process. High Level Healthcare Programming Environment - PENDING 
Instructions, devices and notifications can be "chained" together to help patients perform 
specific healthcare management protocols.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

c0b74a90-2461-433e-b22a-6bf982e30c6d.__data__: {"id_":"c0b74a90-2461-433e-b22a-6bf982e30c6d","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"rMtU7Ur1ylochD0gXXbKi81unjHa2BWxcTUbAAi4roQ=","metadata":{},"hash":"U5BdRVoCgckESTYQVGkTpn/Lg8OY2B5+HNkFuH4/fmo="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"252555b5-a505-4355-bfdc-24849fded61d","metadata":{},"hash":"cCudhWL7jp7voNCqZCfRgwDOonBVbkUh5SJs56VFyFg="}},"hash":"V7roThaRUf8uaoOXmoX2efywAUaxHaF2JInpHSN/IjE=","text":"For example, such a system could guide a patient to \r\nuse a digital stethoscope to \"record heart sounds in Position 3, twice a day, for seven days\".","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"\n","type":"TEXT"}

65a52d7d-1a58-4eee-a6ee-08f797912aed.__data__:
{"id_":"65a52d7d-1a58-4eee-a6ee-08f797912aed","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"7oYHJpsp+ka6MqaPnmcCBDQeAG2ovOcDGzja3o3eh0I=","metadata":{},"hash":"nXyZJB685OilKPCa7ZPSOlt2RQy8iBt32RzPm8uptfo="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"3a8a8f81-2d20-4d57-bd0b-6cef065bbd4b","metadata":{},"hash":"W0Ak/o8kcwk1dlLmqri2+hVTNnJFhRY/iDj78bNaXI4="}},"hash":"cOfBAS9ABvqETVUyCgNM97AalEnwMNIZe29Q/W8ypd0=","text":"That specific instruction, frequency and duration can have notifications such that the user is sent 
reminders, and the healthcare professional is sent results. Virtual Positioning for Virtual Healthcare Consultations - PENDING 
In a virtual healthcare exam, a healthcare professional can position a digital marker/icon on the 
patient’s remote screen, such that the patient is able to orientate the position of a medical 
sensor. Near Real-time Lossless Telehealth Auscultation Audio - PENDING  
In a telehealth exam, audio data may be live-streamed and simultaneously sent to a file 
handling system that downloads the lossless audio data in near real-time. The HCP can then 
access the lossless audio to review the recordings and/or confirm sounds that were heard live. Elephant(s) in the Room (The most asked questions) 
Is this an overcrowded space? No! There are companies with expensive and proprietary diagnostic tools for doctors or 
companies with limited telehealth 1.0 solutions. NO COMPANY has a platform with inexpensive 
FDA-cleared OTC sensors and interoperable software for patients to access value-based chronic 
cardiac and pulmonary diagnostics. Could incumbants copy Medaica strategy? Competiting platform are propriatary don‘t have full suite of sensors or are ~$300+ vs 
Medaica‘s free sensors and are all proprietary. Device companies (as opposed to software 
platforms), depend on high hardware margins. Telehealth platforms do not include sensors. Changing strategy would be a radical culture, org, tech and margin dispruption. Won‘t an army of cheaper sensor companies rush into the market? Sensors alone are not the solution. Even when sensors get cheaper (Moore‘s Law), it is much 
more challnging for them to have FDA clearance for OTC, or be interoperable with virtual health 
A/V and AI solutions. How are the RPM and/or virtual health markets? RPM was worth $14.0 billion in 2023 growing to $41.7 billion by 2028, a CAGR of 20.1 according 
to Markets and Markets, driven by the perfect storm of over-burdened clincs, aging 
populations, expensive healthcare (in USA), and consumer comfort of “Digital First“ will lead to 
remote care that replaces a majority of unnecessary  in-person health visits.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

3a8a8f81-2d20-4d57-bd0b-6cef065bbd4b.__data__:
{"id_":"3a8a8f81-2d20-4d57-bd0b-6cef065bbd4b","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"7oYHJpsp+ka6MqaPnmcCBDQeAG2ovOcDGzja3o3eh0I=","metadata":{},"hash":"nXyZJB685OilKPCa7ZPSOlt2RQy8iBt32RzPm8uptfo="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"65a52d7d-1a58-4eee-a6ee-08f797912aed","metadata":{},"hash":"cOfBAS9ABvqETVUyCgNM97AalEnwMNIZe29Q/W8ypd0="}},"hash":"W0Ak/o8kcwk1dlLmqri2+hVTNnJFhRY/iDj78bNaXI4=","text":"Furthrmore, 
Teleheath 2.0 solutions will augmented s/w will replace the limited Telehealth 1.0 and result in 
higher utility and growth. Who owns the data? Medaica owns the generic, aggregrated, non-identifiable data and has no desire to own 
personally identifiable information. Our licensees own PII. How is the data going to be monetized? Exams and RPM are monetized. Additionally we will charge for longitudinal data, A.I. analyzed 
data, condition-based applications/services, research applications and ecosystem tariffs for 3rd 
Parties. What other conditions/products/services are planned? Following HF, chronic pulminary diagnosis applications are planned. Medaica‘s roadmap also 
includes A.I., other sensors, and opening up the platform (OTIS) to 3rd party devices, apps and 
services. What are Medaica‘s sustainable competitive advantages?","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

53d4a7a7-11af-4621-a6ee-3d64350c7d68.__data__:
{"id_":"53d4a7a7-11af-4621-a6ee-3d64350c7d68","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"eYt8KGiCDnDxjngr1jOiejnJJRyT8ghbZfbdRfi2JUA=","metadata":{},"hash":"SPYW+YViTQm8kMA+Q1FV4uYoDy/IK3JB6p7ahBNGyKc="}},"hash":"mH8RtlDyFfwUN1eh+qQS4RIHu95x6Q30IPx3u7h1Vy4=","text":"FDA clearance, Patents, Free/Scalable consumer device model (Razor/razorblade model), Data 
aggregation (first to get to 10s of millions of HF samples can dominate application and AI area), 
World class team. Who‘s your customer? RPM, Hopsitals, Clinics and Payors/ACOs, motivated to access and support chronic heart and 
lung patients as well as save on readmissions, or offer better outcomes. Ultimately, the 
consumer will pay for services either directly or via their insurance. Won’t Apple, Amazon or Google own this market? They are focused on broader healthcare strategies, which not interoperable. Amazon (via One 
Medical) is less device and service centric, so is a more interesting strategic player. If they are 
interested in what we’re doing, they’d be more likely to acquire us. What‘s a likely exit? Companies like Amazon or Wallmart looking at healthcare as a new consumer market. Google 
looking at the data play. Amwell or Teladoc looking to increase value/reach and stickiness of 
services. Medtronic, Omron, Boston Scientific, etc. Is Medaica a hardware or software business? Medaica is a software platform business. Specifcally, our platform is the enabling middleware 
glue, connecting endpoints between patients and providers. The sensors are Trojan Horses that 
seed our scale. What keeps you up at night? Everything! Execution of new models in a traditional market is always challenging. But that‘s 
also the opportunity.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

8d7513f9-afc4-470e-8da4-e815ed5c6916.__data__:
{"id_":"8d7513f9-afc4-470e-8da4-e815ed5c6916","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"+KIvfAtHC3+MK8IM89XmDTRrZAuyGf1vl8jUv8RY82k=","metadata":{},"hash":"UCLIYA+RTKMKV1NYgOvnixEQlnOz//P2NH3hoxCe1K4="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"42a41b35-88a0-406d-8d03-8f4643863558","metadata":{},"hash":"jUnA2pHno/VxTF+F2Gj0GjzRiSUJbj5+ClESfRdm+/Q="}},"hash":"PeQmwMDIae2mynUebwzRZLK7spLa9Ncqwnj9bLeEzLs=","text":"INTRODUCTION 
Medaica is a digital health company extending the capability of remote exams over any telehealth 
system, simply and affordably. The Company’s first product is a consumer-focused digital stethoscope, 
designed specifically for telehealth systems at a price point that opens up the power and potential of 
remote care to all users. Medaica was founded by serial entrepreneurs with proven global experience in 
MedTech, Healthcare, Consumer Electronics and scaling mass volume hardware and software platforms. THE PROBLEM 
Existing telehealth systems provide video conferencing and/or chat applications, some with scheduling 
management and Electronic Medical Record (EMR) integration. Although telehealth is becoming 
increasingly popular, especially in light of COVID-19, it is currently limited to only a few practice areas, 
such as mental health, dermatology, pediatrics and the common cold. Auscultation is an important part 
of a clinical exam that is missing in telemedicine sessions. Addressing that need, not only has the 
potential to improve the effectiveness of remote care for both the clinician and patient, but also 
improve the utility and value of telehealth. Medaica conducted extensive market research to surface the less obvious challenges of developing a 
product that required some level of behavioral change – both from doctors and consumers. Related to 
the introduction of blood pressure devices, pulse oximeters and, more recently, devices like the Kardia 
EKG, where patients use tools previously available only to clinicians, Medaica understood that clinicians 
AND patients need to recognize and want more valuable telemedicine sessions through such devices. The question was, would this be an acceptable proposition for both sides of the equation? INSIGHTS 
The Medaica design team (based in USA and UK) spoke with many clinicians and received consistent 
feedback that most electronic stethoscopes are too complicated and too expensive for daily use. Furthermore, most electronic stethoscopes cleared by the FDA for use by clinicians, are NOT cleared for 
use by a “lay person” and, in a telemedicine session, it would be the patient, not the doctor, using the 
device. Medaica also interviewed medical IT staff who are often the ones tasked with “making it work. ” IT 
professionals don’t see the “wow” of a new device first but see the increased workload it might present.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

42a41b35-88a0-406d-8d03-8f4643863558.__data__:
{"id_":"42a41b35-88a0-406d-8d03-8f4643863558","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"+KIvfAtHC3+MK8IM89XmDTRrZAuyGf1vl8jUv8RY82k=","metadata":{},"hash":"UCLIYA+RTKMKV1NYgOvnixEQlnOz//P2NH3hoxCe1K4="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"8d7513f9-afc4-470e-8da4-e815ed5c6916","metadata":{},"hash":"PeQmwMDIae2mynUebwzRZLK7spLa9Ncqwnj9bLeEzLs="}},"hash":"jUnA2pHno/VxTF+F2Gj0GjzRiSUJbj5+ClESfRdm+/Q=","text":"Incumbent proprietary solutions can create workflow silos that become increasingly difficult to manage 
and support. Solution providers need to understand and appreciate the time-consuming process of 
integrating IT services, devices and systems, and must not assume a doctor, clinic, or hospital will 
willingly adopt yet another proprietary solution. If every medical device only works with a specific  
telehealth platform, those devices ultimately become unsupported islands. That is not a sustainable 
strategy for a business or a medical practice. At a detailed level, on top of familiar “hot button” issues including but not limited to data privacy and 
development of more telehealth pay-codes etc., examples of the less obvious but real-world challenges 
facing clinicians that also surfaced were: 
• Artificial Intelligence AI, even when positioned as “Assisted Intelligence” which is arguably a 
friendlier and more accurate term of art, was often received as a threat not a benefit; At best it was","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

e0918922-8fae-4469-8bfd-c058fd7b25d2.__data__:
{"id_":"e0918922-8fae-4469-8bfd-c058fd7b25d2","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"V4iQtTH3f1U0dkQ4NKNUY3jIIlTL3Juz4uskRU2w1+0=","metadata":{},"hash":"YAVyfWMbeY0dTa1nNLJBnGtHOsEV/bNq7IU/b8Yt9Ow="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"1a205e1b-b7ff-4e22-ad15-4b87559a3c1c","metadata":{},"hash":"QZXGjtmyrPIzesA4Mw6QLR4ZyFw6yn0Dy1fvaEBWHoM="}},"hash":"j3X2ZdMm+qU5gb2E6Zpyxz0istikwVSrM6bt22ukEhA=","text":"a partial solution. For example, if a company offered an electronic stethoscope with AI that helps 
diagnose atrial fibrillation, the clinician still needed other devices, tests and protocols to diagnose 
other conditions such as arrhythmias, congenital heart disease, coronary artery disease, 
cardiomyopathy etc. • Besides often generating a myriad of pairing issues, connecting a Bluetooth stethoscope during a 
telehealth session resulted in that device taking over the audio channel and the clinician being 
unable to talk with the patient. • Devices that might not function before or during an exam because the battery was drained. • Single purpose devices that often cost several hundred dollars were deemed not economically viable 
for a scalable solution and therefore did not warrant the time investment on the clinician’s side to 
evaluate and/or integrate. The resulting Venn diagram that became Medaica’s mantra, was for its solutions to be; Affordable, 
Simple and Interoperable. THE SOLUTION 
Among Medaica’s many different design decisions, was their choice of using a USB cable (with adaptors 
for any laptop, desktop or mobile device) rather than Bluetooth. That simplified the electronic design 
and user experience, reduced the cost, avoided potential interference issues and removed the need for 
batteries. As a USB device, the Medaica stethoscope is “plug and play” and in its simplest form can 
securely send audio files, together with an “auscultation map” to the clinician either in store and 
forward or live modes. The product design went through a number of iterations. It needed to be easy to hold but also easy to 
position in relation to the patient being able to position the device on an “auscultation map” in self-
exam mode. One of the early designs was essentially a stethoscope head but was rejected because the 
user’s hand would be covering the head and/or made a simple button push awkward (see Figs 1 & 2). Fig 1. Awkward button placement (thumb)                                   Fig 2. OK button placement, but obscures head position 
The chosen design direction was to be more recognizably a stethoscope (See Fig.3). The head of the 
device is easy to see (or detect for assisted positioning approaches) when the user is placing the device 
in a specific auscultation position.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

1a205e1b-b7ff-4e22-ad15-4b87559a3c1c.__data__:
{"id_":"1a205e1b-b7ff-4e22-ad15-4b87559a3c1c","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"V4iQtTH3f1U0dkQ4NKNUY3jIIlTL3Juz4uskRU2w1+0=","metadata":{},"hash":"YAVyfWMbeY0dTa1nNLJBnGtHOsEV/bNq7IU/b8Yt9Ow="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"e0918922-8fae-4469-8bfd-c058fd7b25d2","metadata":{},"hash":"j3X2ZdMm+qU5gb2E6Zpyxz0istikwVSrM6bt22ukEhA="}},"hash":"QZXGjtmyrPIzesA4Mw6QLR4ZyFw6yn0Dy1fvaEBWHoM=","text":"The design is easy to manufacture and can be completely sealed and 
therefore also has the advantage that it is washable to IP6X standards. These decisions were made prior 
to COVID-19 flaring up but become even more compelling within that context.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}

4e363050-5494-489d-92d7-10c1827a7a84.__data__:
{"id_":"4e363050-5494-489d-92d7-10c1827a7a84","metadata":{},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"zNP0hATIqCx/t6VZyHqbLYv2IZInAZY6/75iIrO3F40=","metadata":{},"hash":"Thv3lYTP1kp7+FxgFbT/Uln+T03uBngdJbTwZKdr92A="}},"hash":"2SOZOqVAd0x0I3qfpZtFCKV9eDyOXlcrZHm3FeQbi6c=","text":"Fig 3. Good button placement, good visibility of head position, comfortable to hold and separate body/voice mics. There were many technology decisions not only aimed at making the device easy to use, but easy to 
deploy and to potentially establish standard telehealth methods for patients and clinicians to quickly 
and easily share auscultation sounds. One of those decisions was to use two microphones configured for 
plug and play with any telehealth system, enabling both auscultation sounds and an independent 
channel for the user to speak, which also doubles for ambient/room noise reduction. Because Medaica’s solutions are designed to enhance existing telehealth solutions, not compete with 
them, they worked extremely hard to make sure that the clinician could continue to use whatever 
system they were already using, with the added benefit of adding auscultation to the exam. The pillars 
of that process were: 
• Balance clinician AND patient ease of use to get a more valuable and informed telehealth 
consultation for both sides. • Enable healthcare professionals to leverage existing workflows and systems. • Don’t compete with telehealth platforms – provide plug and play, agnostic, interoperability to any 
telehealth platform. Enable value-add to open their platforms to new specialties and stickier users. • KISS  (Keep It Simple Solutions) – solutions that work in the minimum number of steps with minimal 
behavioral change. • Affordable  – solutions that are priced for consumer scale. For more information about the Medaica Telehealth Stethoscope visit www.medaica.com.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT"}
